items.title: U.S. Tech Firms Facing Stronger European Data Protection Measures
items.author: By Natasha Singer
items.abstract: Over the last year, American regulators and technology trade groups have tried to contain an effort by the European Commission to increase data protection regulations for Europeans. That may not be enough to slow the momentum in Europe.

items.title: Europe to Consider Creating Data Protection Regulator
items.author: By Kevin J. O'Brien
items.abstract: If approved, the proposal would replace an advisory panel with an agency with the power to levy fines on companies who violate rules on the use of information gathered online.

items.title: A Digital Paradise by the Dashboard Light
items.author: By Phil Patton
items.abstract: The automobiles displayed this year at the Detroit auto show suggest a quiet revolution: digital is chasing the last vestiges of analog from the dashboard. The dial is dying.
keywords: Cadillac Division of General Motors Corp
Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp

items.title: Old Technology Modernizes a Camera Sensor
items.author: By Roy Furchgott
items.abstract: Fuji’s newest consumer cameras use a trick from analog photography to reduce graininess and increase resolution in its digital light sensors.

items.title: Report Points to Risk of Serious Gap in Weather Satellite Data
items.author: By Dylan Walsh
items.abstract: The Government Accountability Office raises the prospect of a 17- to 53-month gap in data from satellites that could impede weather forecasting.

items.title: The Promise and Peril of the ‘Data-Driven Society’
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: The prospect of a “data-driven society” was the subject of a gathering last Thursday at the M.I.T. Media Lab — the implications, the concerns and the unknowns. For example, the most important data that is becoming available on a vast new scale is information about people’s behavior: the social and economic connections among individuals.

items.title: App Smart Extra: Looking for Real Estate Rentals
items.author: By Kit Eaton
items.abstract: Several real-estate apps offer special tools for renters.

items.title: Technology’s Impact on the Value of Financial Advice
items.author: By Paul Sullivan
items.abstract: Financial advisers are putting greater emphasis on technology, but it is unclear whether that is better for their clients.

items.title: Street Smarts: From Holland, Bright Ideas for Highways
items.author: By Paul Hockenos
items.abstract: Under a Dutch plan, “smart” roads would include glow-in-the-dark markings, interactive streetlights, battery-charging e-lanes and illuminated foul-weather warnings.

items.title: How Big Data Is Playing Recruiter for Specialized Workers
items.author: By Matt Richtel
items.abstract: In industries where good talent can be hard to find, companies are using algorithms to scour the Web for recruits, and in the process, they are challenging some traditional notions of hiring.

items.title: Digital Coach Perched Right in Your Pocket
items.author: By Josh Dean
items.abstract: Companies have started to introduce some intriguing sports devices that analyze movement using sensors.

items.title: Technology Is Not Driving Us Apart After All
items.author: By Mark Oppenheimer
items.abstract: It turns out, we may be more social than we were 30 years ago — at least in public spaces.

items.title: Spy Agencies Tap Data Streaming From Phone Apps
items.author: By James Glanz, Jeff Larson and Andrew W. Lehren
items.abstract: As personal data pour onto mobile networks, American and British eavesdroppers are prying into so-called leaky apps to extract geographical data, address books and phone logs, secret documents show.

items.title: Better Eating With Smart Scales and Forks
items.author: By Catherine Saint Louis
items.abstract: A scale that provides calorie counts and a nutritional breakdown for home-cooked food, and a fork that encourages leisurely eating.

items.title: Wind Industry’s New Technologies Are Helping It Compete on Price
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.

items.title: Tachyus, a Data Start-Up for Oil Industry, Raises $6 Million From Founders Fund
items.author: By Michael J. de la Merced
items.abstract: The start-up is an anomaly of sorts in Silicon Valley because it aims to create an array of sensors and mobile applications to help oil and gas producers better record and analyze their wells.

items.title: Huge New York Development Project Becomes a Data Science Lab
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: The developers of the Hudson Yards on Manhattan’s West Side are forming a partnership with the researchers at N.Y.U.’s Center for Urban Science and Progress to create a “quantified community” that uses data science to study and improve the urban environment.

items.title: ‘Smart’ Firearm Draws Wrath of the Gun Lobby
items.author: By Jeremy W. Peters
items.abstract: A handgun that can identify its user so no one else can fire it has met with the same uproar that has stopped many seeking tougher weapons laws.

items.title: Israeli Military Officials Caught Off Guard by a ‘Digital Rebellion’
items.author: By Jodi Rudoren
items.abstract: Israeli Defense Forces officials were caught off guard by the online outcry over a disciplinary case.

items.title: Tracking Data Use to Avoid Hefty Phone Fees
items.author: By Kit Eaton
items.abstract: A number of apps can help monitor and manage data consumption on phones, to keep you within your plan’s limits and avert unpleasant surprises on your bill.

items.title: Extracting Data from a Dead Tablet
items.author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
items.abstract: Exploring alternatives to taking a hammer to that glossy electronic brick.

items.title: Dressing for the Digital Divide
items.author: By Vanessa Friedman
items.abstract: Versace, Bottega Veneta, Jil Sander and others are focusing on a blend of the past and the future.

items.title: Capturing the Night in Digital Photos, Spectacularly
items.author: By Farhad Manjoo
items.abstract: A photographer shows how improvements in camera sensors and software and in postproduction software have made it possible to take excellent photos at night.

items.title: Kushner Brothers Combine Real Estate and Technology
items.author: By Michael J. de la Merced
items.abstract: Their start-up, Cadre, which aims to make it easier for select clients to invest in real estate, has raised more than $18.3 million.

items.title: A Deadline for Greece, and U.S. Jobs Data
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Greece is hoping to gain approval for its economic plans on Monday so its rescuers will release the next round of bailout aid; United States employment data is due on Friday.

items.title: Smart City Technology May Be Vulnerable to Hackers
items.author: By Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: A security researcher has found that the sensor technology being used to control everything from traffic lights to water systems is often installed and managed without proper security measures.

items.title: Germany Limits Cooperation With U.S. Over Data Gathering
items.author: By Alison Smale
items.abstract: While the practical restrictions are not clear, the move suggests tensions over security versus civil liberties have stoked a rift between the two allies.

items.title: Singapore’s Postal Service Reinvents Itself for the Digital Age
items.author: By Alexandra Stevenson
items.abstract: With traditional mail fading, SingPost has transformed into a provider of logistics and marketing services to companies eager to tap the e-commerce boom in Asia.

items.title: The Future of Car Keys? Smartphone Apps, Maybe
items.author: By Eric A. Taub
items.abstract: Apps are increasingly performing the functions of keys, but experts say there are still kinks to be worked out before, and if, physical keys become extinct.

items.title: Girl Scout Cookie Sales Go Digital, With Help From Visa and Dell
items.author: By Elizabeth Olson
items.abstract: The Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. permitted web sales of cookies for the first time in 2015, and Visa and Dell are investing an estimated $3 million this year to help improve the platform.

items.title: New York Public Library Invites a Deep Digital Dive
items.author: By Jennifer Schuessler
items.abstract: The library is releasing over 180,000 photographs, maps and other public-domain items in downloadable high-resolution files for patrons to use as they wish.

items.title: Microsoft Plumbs Ocean’s Depths to Test Underwater Data Center
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: Microsoft sank a data center on the ocean floor, where the sea water acts as a coolant, and plans to use the waves to power it. The results were encouraging enough to try a bigger version.

items.title: Technology to Make Clean Energy From Coal Is Stumbling in Practice
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: A large-scale project in Canada to capture carbon from a coal-burning power plant has fallen short of its goal and its costs are soaring.

items.title: Italy’s Goldsmiths Mix Technology With Tradition
items.author: By Laura Rysman
items.abstract: Heritage houses use modern advances to create pieces ‘impossible to make by hand.’

items.title: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.

items.title: ‘Walking Dead’ Digital Comic, The Alien, Is Pay What You Wish
items.author: By George Gene Gustines
items.abstract: The Walking Dead: The Alien is by Brian K. Vaughan and Marcos Martin of Panel Syndicate, not the usual team of Robert Kirkman and Charlie Adlard.

items.title: Oil-Services Companies FMC Technologies and Technip Plan Merger
items.author: By Stanley Reed
items.abstract: The all-stock deal, worth $13 billion, would combine the American and French companies, which have been hit hard by the global plunge in energy prices.

items.title: In Audi’s Virtual Cockpit, Technology Is Your Co-Pilot
items.author: By Stephen Williams
items.abstract: Audi is the first carmaker to offer the screen, which replaces traditional dials like the speedometer, and can also show maps, radio and other functions.

items.title: Three Young Artists Interpret Reality in a Digital Era
items.author: By Hilary Moss
items.abstract: Britta Thie, Rachel Rose and Timur Si-Qin talk about their pieces that are featured in Julia Stoschek Collection’s first Berlin exhibition.

items.title: Can Carbon Capture Technology Prosper Under Trump?
items.author: By John Schwartz
items.abstract: Progress has come in fits and starts, but supporters believe a new plant in Texas may provide a clear economic argument for fighting global warming.

items.title: Falcons, Drones, Data: A Winery Battles Climate Change
items.author: By David Gelles
items.abstract: Jackson Family Wines is among California winemakers employing both high-tech and old-school techniques to adapt to hotter, drier conditions.

items.title: Trump Responds to Louvre Attack in Paris, Urging U.S. to ‘Get Smart’
items.author: By Jonathan Weisman, Emmarie Huetteman and Matt Flegenheimer
items.abstract: After a soldier shot a machete-wielding attacker at the museum, President Trump chimed in on Twitter, apparently urging support for his policies.

items.title: Ford to Invest $1 Billion in Artificial Intelligence Start-Up
items.author: By Mike Isaac and Neal E. Boudette
items.abstract: The automaker will be the majority shareholder Argo AI, which will focus on developing self-driving vehicle technology.

items.title: Modern Potboilers at Prada and Moschino
items.author: By Vanessa Friedman
items.abstract: While Miuccia Prada took another look at the mystery of seduction and smarts, Jeremy Scott pondered the problem of consumption.

items.title: Opposing Views on What to Do About the Data We Create
items.author: By Amy Webb
items.abstract: Andreas Weigend, in “Data for the People,” and Kevin Mitnick, in “The Art of Invisibility,” are alarmed about data mining and the loss of privacy.
keywords: Data for the People: How to Make Our Post-Privacy Economy Work for You (Book)
The Art of Invisibility: The World's Most Famous Hacker Teaches You How to Be Safe in the Age of Big Brother and Big Data (Book)

items.title: Pro Golfers Find Winning Rounds From Numbers Crunching
items.author: By Adam Schupak
items.abstract: Data analysts use the sport’s vast statistics to create strategies tailored to individual players and their strengths, raising their earnings.

items.title: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation
items.author: By Steph Yin
items.abstract: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.

items.title: ‘Take That for Data’ Punctuates Fizdale’s Officiating Rant
items.author: By Victor Mather
items.abstract: The Memphis Grizzlies coach let his displeasure with the refs be known in a news conference after the team lost to the Spurs, 96-82, on Monday night.

items.title: On the Whole30 Diet, Vowing to Eat ‘Smarter’ Carbs for More Than 30 Days
items.author: By Larissa Zimberoff
items.abstract: I have Type 1 diabetes. The Whole30 diet, with no wheat, dairy or sugar, made my blood sugar levels perfect.

items.title: School Shooting Simulation Trains Teachers for the Worst
items.author: By Jason M. Bailey
items.abstract: New software funded by the Department of Homeland Security features a virtual school stalked by an active shooter.

items.title: How Trump Consultants Exploited the Facebook Data of Millions
items.author: By Matthew Rosenberg, Nicholas Confessore and Carole Cadwalladr
items.abstract: Cambridge Analytica harvested personal information from a huge swath of the electorate to develop techniques that were later used in the Trump campaign.
keywords: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

items.title: Russia, North Korea, Data: Your Wednesday Briefing
items.author: By Dan Levin
items.abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

items.title: At the Masters, Low-Tech Data Still Rules
items.author: By Karen Crouse
items.abstract: At Augusta National, caddies and players receive yardage books that provide rudimentary information compared with what is often available at other tournaments. So they have to fill in the blanks.

items.title: Standing Up at Your Desk Could Make You Smarter
items.author: By Richard A. Friedman
items.abstract: We knew sitting too much was bad for the body. Now we know it’s bad for the brain.

items.title: M.T.A. Pins Its Hopes on Unproven Technology to Fix Subway
items.author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
items.abstract: Subway officials hope ultra-wideband radio will help modernize the signal system, but the technology has not been used on a major transit system.

items.title: The Sights and Smells of Sicily’s Second City
items.author: By Lucas Peterson
items.abstract: While it doesn’t attract the same kind of attention as Palermo, Catania seems to be getting ready for its moment in the spotlight.

items.title: One Smart Coach: How Are the Rockets Getting Away With All That Dribbling?
items.author: By Scott Cacciola
items.abstract: Eric Musselman used to coach the Warriors, and prefers their style of play. He marvels at what the Rockets are doing in the conference finals.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.author: By Timothy Williams
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Smart Lights Are the One Smart Home Gadget for Everyone
items.author: By Eric Ravenscraft
items.abstract: Expensive smart home gadgets are still niche and of limited use. Smart lights, on the other hand, are useful to just about everyone.

items.title: In Baseball’s Game of Numbers, Yankees Differ on Which Ones Count
items.author: By James Wagner
items.abstract: The team has a robust analytics department, but the players vary widely in terms of which statistics they focus on.

items.title: The Lewis and Clark of the Digital Building Frontier
items.author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
items.abstract: These married architects are democratizing the 3-D printing process, using materials destined for the trash heap — like curry powder and coffee grounds — in place of drywall and foam.

items.title: Review: ‘Smart Blonde’ Revisits a Star of Old Hollywood
items.author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
items.abstract: Willy Holtzman’s play, with the storytelling quality of PowerPoint, offers a biography of Judy Holliday, an award-winning actress who died young.

items.title: Can Technology Stop the Duane Reade-ization of New York?
items.author: By Britta Lokting
items.abstract: Pharmaceutical delivery apps like Capsule offer an alternative to drugstores. Whether they could spell the end to commercial chains is up for debate.

items.title: What Students Are Saying About: Digital Memories, Youth Sports and Movie Theaters
items.author: By The Learning Network
items.abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts — and an invitation to tell us what they’re reading in The Times.

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Drive Smarter
items.author: By Lisa Friedman and Eduardo Garcia
items.abstract: Also this week, climate report cards for Democratic candidates.

items.title: Digital Jail: How Electronic Monitoring Drives Defendants Into Debt
items.author: By Ava Kofman
items.abstract: Ankle bracelets are promoted as a humane alternative to jail. But private companies charge defendants hundreds of dollars a month to wear the surveillance devices. If people can’t pay, they may end up behind bars.

items.title: He Overcame Setbacks to Thrive in Information Technology
items.author: By John L. Dorman
items.abstract: Five years ago, Darius Jones had trouble coming up with subway fare. Today, he is an I.T. analyst for one of the world’s most exclusive luxury brands.
keywords: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
Community Service Society of New York

items.title: Data Driving New Approaches to Transportation
items.author: By Norman Mayersohn
items.abstract: Analyzing digital streams of information from electric scooters and motor-assisted bicycles is helping solve travel congestion issues.

items.title: In the Age of Digital Streaming, Are Movie Theaters Still Relevant?
items.author: By Shannon Doyne
items.abstract: How is watching a movie in a theater different from streaming it at home? On what occasion do you think it’s worth venturing out to see a movie on the big screen? Or, to you, is it never worth it?

items.title: In Coronavirus Fight, China Gives Citizens a Color Code, With Red Flags
items.author: By Paul Mozur, Raymond Zhong and Aaron Krolik
items.abstract: A new system uses software to dictate quarantines — and appears to send personal data to police, in a troubling precedent for automated social control.

items.title: Stocking Your Pantry, the Smart Way
items.author: By Melissa Clark
items.abstract: Here’s what you really need to keep on hand.

items.title: Can Smart Thermometers Track the Spread of the Coronavirus?
items.author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
items.abstract: A company that makes internet-connected thermometers has followed the flu more closely than the C.D.C. can. Now the devices may be turning up cases of Covid-19.
keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

items.title: Coronavirus Kills 758 in New York but Data Suggest Spread Is Slowing
items.abstract: Governor Cuomo and Mayor de Blasio continued to spar over New York City schools on Sunday.

items.title: Earth Day’s Gone Digital. Here’s Where to Find It.
items.author: By Laurel Graeber
items.abstract: New York offers many ways to celebrate online. You can hike, play environmental games, conduct experiments, meet scientists and blast into space — all without leaving home.
keywords: Museum of the City of New York

items.title: A QAnon ‘Digital Soldier’ Marches On, Undeterred by Theory’s Unraveling
items.author: By Kevin Roose
items.abstract: Valerie Gilbert posts dozens of times a day in support of an unhinged conspiracy theory. The story of this “meme queen” hints at how hard it will be to bring people like her back to reality.

items.title: Review: Beware the Text, and Other Tales From ‘Smithtown’
items.author: By Jesse Green
items.abstract: Four not-very-believable characters in a chain of monologues are rescued by a cast of exceptionally believable actors.

items.title: The Soothing, Digital Rooms of YouTube
items.author: By Eliza Brooke
items.abstract: Ambience videos pair relaxing soundscapes with animated scenery to make viewers feel immersed in specific spaces, like a cozy library. They’re big with “Harry Potter” fans.

items.title: You’re New Here, Aren’t You? Digital Theater’s Unexpected Upside
items.author: By Michael Paulson
items.abstract: Companies and venues that put work online are finding big, new and younger audiences — but little revenue.
keywords: Lied Center for Performing Arts (Lincoln, Neb)

items.title: Still Getting Your Head Around Digital Currency? So Are Central Bankers.
items.author: By Jeanna Smialek
items.abstract: If you are trying to grasp Bitcoin and understand what China’s digital yuan means, America’s Federal Reserve is right there with you.

items.title: How Data Is Changing the Way Offices Are Run
items.author: By Patrick Sisson
items.abstract: Building owners are using data collection and artificial intelligence to help control systems like heating, lighting, air quality and even the flow of workers.

items.title: Three Dramas Explore the Margins of the Digital Form
items.author: By Jesse Green
items.abstract: Talking dogs, green screen thrillers and gold turtles: Online productions, intended as a stopgap, are testing the boundaries of what makes theater theater.

items.title: For a New Troupe, Going Digital Has Been Easier Than Returning Live
items.author: By Stuart Miller
items.abstract: Molière in the Park garnered praise for Zoom productions of “Tartuffe” and other plays. Putting on an outdoor show in Brooklyn has been another matter.

items.title: Seven European countries begin issuing a digital Covid certificate for travel.
items.author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
items.abstract: The European Union plans to roll them out to all member states by July 1, and to eventually make them available to travelers from outside the bloc.

items.title: Digital Be Damned! Welcome to Shows You Can Touch and Feel.
items.author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
items.abstract: Fuzzy puppet sheep. A light cutting through the haze. Hand-designed dreamscapes. There’s plenty to savor in the slow return of pixel-free theater.
keywords: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

items.title: With Sensors on Streets, France Takes Aim at ‘Noise From Hell’
items.author: By Emma Bubola
items.abstract: The French authorities are installing “sound radars” in some cities to detect and photograph vehicles making excessive noise, which they say is a public health hazard.

items.title: When It Comes to Wordle Strategies, It’s Personal
items.author: By Emma Dibdin
items.abstract: Aficionados of the deceptively simple word game, including Monica Lewinsky and J. Smith-Cameron, weigh in with their opening gambits.

items.title: Weight Watchers App Gathered Data From Children, F.T.C. Says
items.author: By Claire Fahy
items.abstract: Kurbo by WW, a weight-loss app geared toward children, illegally collected data from users as young as 8 without their parents’ consent, the Federal Trade Commission said in a complaint.

items.title: A New City, Built Upon Data, Takes Shape in South Korea
items.author: By David Belcher
items.abstract: Fifty-four families volunteered to share data on everything from sleeping habits to trash volume to help developers make a city from scratch in Busan.

items.title: With Balls Traveling Farther, the Masters Tries to Keep Up
items.author: By Paul Sullivan
items.abstract: Modern golf balls and clubs are challenging older courses. How much longer can Augusta National withstand the new technology?

items.title: Football Tech That’s More Than a Laser and Light Show
items.author: By Kevin Randall
items.abstract: The U.S.F.L. is testing tech that could resolve disputes over where balls are spotted, clearly show if a first down was reached and track players who stand too high on tackles. The N.F.L. is watching.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: Some Muslims Are Using Digital Rings to Track Their Praises to God
items.author: By Raja Abdulrahim
items.abstract: Much like the fitness tools that count steps, these electronic devices help keep a record of the day’s religious recitations.

items.title: The Smart Set Sneered, but the Play Won the Day
items.author: By Eric Grode
items.abstract: One hundred years ago this month, the interfaith marriage comedy “Abie’s Irish Rose” kicked off a five-year Broadway run — critics be damned.

items.title: From Car Sensors to Archaeological Maps, Laser Technology Proves a Bright Idea
items.author: By The Learning Network
items.abstract: We are honoring the top eight winners of our Student STEM Writing Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Anya Zhang.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: A Smarter Way to Reduce Gun Deaths
items.author: By Nicholas Kristof
items.abstract: To break the paralysis, focus less on guns and more on those firing them.

items.title: Classified U.S. Report Highlights Foreign Power Aerial Spying With Advanced Tech
items.author: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
items.abstract: Before a Chinese spy balloon was discovered in the United States, American officials said a rival power may have used advanced technology to surveil U.S. military sites.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Soul Told Black Musicians’ Stories. Its Archives Are Going Digital.
items.author: By Christopher Petkanas
items.abstract: The newspaper, which started in 1966 with a focus on R&B, funk and disco, shut down in 1982. But one of its founders’ grandsons is devoted to finding it a new online audience.

items.title: Remember Pamela Smart? ‘To Die For’ Convict Now Seeks Mercy.
items.author: By Corey Kilgannon
items.abstract: The woman who became a national sensation in 1990 after her teenage lover killed her husband has become a prison preacher. She hopes New Hampshire will set her free.

items.title: A Once-Promising Green Energy Technology Hits a Roadblock
items.author: By Ian Austen
items.abstract: Tidal power turbines operating on the Bay of Fundy in Nova Scotia were suspended after the company running them was unable to get a permit to continue testing.
